Topic.Title: SCAMAZON: JAN2014 LEAP PUTS ONLY WEAPON TO WIN AGAINST BEZOS CRIMINAL HEDGE FUND GANG

Message.Msg: So, where's our stimulus? Like good little Pavlovian dogs, we ran back into the markets last week when Mario Draghi rang the stimulus bill – increasing the $60Tn global markets by 5% – that's $3Tn of valuation added in 48 hours on the say-so of a former GS executive that has been put in charge of the European Central bank. What could possibly go wrong with this scenario? If we can't trust the Investment Bankers who are taking over our Government, who can we trust? So we'll assume that everything WILL be fixed this week and that the ECB, Fed, PBOC, BOE, BOJ and all the little Central Banksters will be pumping enough money into the system to justify a $3,000,000,000,000 increase in Global Equity prices – even though that means, at an average p/e of 15, that all this expected stimulus somehow drops an additional $200Bn to the bottom line of Big Business to justify the bump in valuation. How many Dollars, Yen, Euros and Yuan do we have to give to Corporations to turn into $200Bn? Well, if it's AMZN – the answer is $15Tn because it takes $50Bn in sales for AMZN to make $600M so figure 75x in sales to make 1x in earnings. Why use AMZN? Well because AMZN is almost 5% of the Nasdaq and it was their amazing run last week, on what rational people would consider poor earnings, that reversed the downtrend initiates by AAPL's (who are 15% of the Nasdaq) miss. I guess it's obvious why we're short AMZN but let's look at AAPL now, who are quite a bit more efficient at dropping Dollars to the bottom line. Last year, AAPL took in $108Bn and made a profit of $26Bn – now THAT'S a good company! So let's pretend that all companies are as good as AAPL and nowhere near as bad as AMZN at converting sales to profits. Now to get that additional $200Bn in Corporate Profits we only need about $800Bn in stimulus – assuming, of course, that money actually went to people who would spend it and not to Banksters who are still trying to back-fill multi-Trillion Dollar holes in their mark-to-fantasy balance sheets. $800Bn is a doable number so let's pretend it is enough to justify a 5% bump in the market and now we know what we'll be needing this week…

Message.Title: Margins going up?
Message.Msg: While it is true that gross margins have improved or due to cost of sales, every other cost item: fulfillment, marketing, technology and SG&A have grown faster than sales. These costs are real and will not go away like the argument about capital investments declining after years of heavy investments. So one could argue that the cost to do a dollar of sales has gone up and not down despite getting closer to the customer with the new warehouses. There is also a need to question what all these dollars spent on acquisitions are really providing. Can they be maintenance capex to really keep the business up to date? There is always the excuse about Europe slowing down, but this is just part of doing business, so I really don't understand how Wall Street is not more skeptical about these results which basically show declines in almost every metric. Cardboard

And lets say they grown their sales from 64B to 72B. Then you thing the stock should go up to $500 for sure, right?? Well, what you would have is Target...presently with $4.40 in earning, paying a respectable dividend with 72B in sales and a market cap of 40M. By my calculations if they do everything right they should be trading @ $100. - PJ

Topic.Title: Does AMZN make 16c or 1c this quarter?

Message.Msg: Have you done a discounted cash flow analysis to determine how much to pay for future earnings? Based on next year's earnings estimates, AMZN would have to stay in business for 200 years just to justify their current valuation, assuming they grew earnings at the same rate as the discount rate you are using. Obviously you must expect them to grow earnings much faster than that, but there's been no evidence that they will be able to, in fact earnings have been declining.

Message.Title: One sale from Bezos and all major fund longs begin selling
Message.Msg: When any one of the large holders realizes that now is the best time he will ever get to sell, and the rest of them recognize the situation unfolding, it starts a long term descent that never recovers..like every other bubble. All the critics are seeing facts correctly, because those are here today and fundamentally true. The babble is keeping the major longs in the game,but they are quite accustomed to the process.One sale from Bezos and the whole game ends. Maybe this run up is a way of getting some of his first large order.Its valuable information,keeps his cash under management potentially and decent commission dollars to boot.

This is a very lousy excuse for not delivering profits. This is nothing more than mismanagement of resources and misguided vision. The costs associated with these capital investments will be amortized over a period of several years and will continue to impact earnings adversely. The projected increased in revenues as a result of these investments are over-stated and remains a fantasy at this point. Good companies invest into the future but continue to deliver good earnings (not a penny/sh and projected loss for the next qtr).

Message.Title: the bull case for amzn article...
Message.Msg: neglected to include price to sales ratios which makes amzn look incredibly overvalued compared to its' peers...in some cases 15 times more expensive in that regard. Every other retailer online and bricks and mortar expand without using expansion as an excuse for poor earnings. They all have to expand and do so while maintaing competitive earnings. For some reason, amzn does not. Amzn also is excused from sales tax in 46 states...shipping costs will go up as ups, fedex and others pay more for fuel and operating costs and their own expansions. The bull case for amzn is bullsh*it! This company has priced in 20 years of growth and its' only 15 years old. Spare me the "new economy blabber".

Message.Title: the bull case for amzn article...

Message.Title: Why AMZN will never be able to compete with WMT
Message.Msg: 1) AMZN has to pay for "the last mile." Anyone with any modicum of knowledge of logistics know this is the MOST EXPENSIVE MILE! Remember the online grocery company that delivered your food to your house? 2) AMZN doesn't have the buying power of WMT on anything that can't be delivered online. AMZN could compete with Barnes and Noble on buying power because books can be delivered online. 3) AMZN has to pay Ebay for a large part of their sales. The list goes on.....
New model/ old model: it's all good for amzn always: again and again: that's what i've learned over the years.

Topic.Title: Does AMZN make 16c or 1c this quarter?

Message.Msg: "the reference was to "do earnings matter", not whether it was .01 or .16." Ah, my "does it really matter" reference was to .01 vs .16.

Jeff and his CFO keep telling the AMZN 'investors' that insteand of profits they are building warehouses. To build a warehouse I think you need 3 items 1) a building, ; 2) inventory and 3) employees. Item 1 is a capital cost, which does not impact earnings. Items 2 and 3 are expenses that do impact current earnings. So, if Amazon has been spending money adding warehouses, why have the 'Inventories' on the Balance sheet dropped from $4,992MM on Dec 31, 2011 to $4,380MM on June 31,2012? Maybe they are going to use the new warehouses to store and ship the hot-air coming from Jeff B and his CFO.

Topic.Title: Does AMZN make 16c or 1c this quarter?

Message.Msg: Well $50 million or the equivalent of $0.15 a share was from non-operating income. The US Dollar gained vs the Euro and other currencies so balances on books (payables) in other currencies got an accounting boost. It's ironic Amazon estimates that it lost $16 million in revenue from FX changes, but fails to disclose that they gained $50 million from FX changes as well. If the USD didn't go up in a big way, Amazon would of reported a losss in Q2.

Message.Title: Serious Question
Message.Msg: Do you think Amazon will lose more prime customers due to the sales tax issue. I have been a prime member, but I didn't renew, and I don't buy much from Amazon anymore due to the sales tax. I can order from several other online stores for the same pricing without paying the sales tax. I may be the exception and not the rule. If there are more people like me I would think it would affect their streaming business too.

Message.Msg: "Well $50 million or the equivalent of $0.15 a share was from non-operating income" there's a bigger point being made here: whether it's 16 cents or 1 cent or 16 cents loss, we are still at this stage in the AMZN game talking about "cents" when the freakin' stock is almost 240/share. That wasn't the originial scenario sold to the public and argues to the degree of how big the scam has become. Should be talking about multiple dollars/share by now not cents snooping. In other words, the goons are still playing around while AMZN is not tethered to any value here. And we've gone beyond caring about earnings long ago. Scary stuff. cheers.

Sales tax will affect all Internet retailers. Perhaps you didn't renew because you did not not feel your streaming selection was worth $6/ month. I have Netflix and its worth $8/ month.

Kenji: I've trimmed my puts in CMG significantly. The difference is simple. CMG generates cash. A lot of it. It will continue to because its unit economics are simply superior AT A LOW MINIMUM EFFICIENT SCALE. CMG talks about ShopHouse to give WS is BS option growth story, but it stays focused on optimizing the unit economics and generating cash. If the economy gets really ugly, CMG will still generate cash (simply slow expansion). While the stock price will get hit for "slowing growth" (and thus CMG remains a good short), CMG is in infinitely better position to withstand a contraction now than AMZN is. AMZN is taking on more fixed costs at EXACTLY the wrong time.

Actually, the legislation hasn't passed. And, it is highly likely that smaller merchants (below some sales threshold that is being fought over) will not have to collect (thus why eBay and SCAMAZON are on different sides of this one). Now that Amazon is a big boy, it doesn't want the little guys to have the same advantage that was central to getting it to where it is today. The ideal outcome is for it to pass with a reasonable threshold (say $10MM annual revenue in wholly owned or majority controlled businesses). That will be great for eBay (and little electronics retailers) and hose Amazon. Regardless, Amazon is in trouble going forward. Its aggressive CapEx heading into a tightening and likely competitive responses from the titans with whom it picked fights is going to create real pain for shareholders stupid enough to hold into Q4...
Yes, care to comment on his Chipotle debacle?
or for that matter what about Netflix. He said it was a buy at $300 and that it was ok for them to raise prices.

Topic.Title: When US starts to tighten like Europe...

Message.Msg: Tech, I learned a lot about patients and timing during that 18 week stretch this spring trying to short CMG. I closed my PNRA put position today at the lows for a respectful gain. Will wait for 170-175 there before committing any more capital. Amzn whipsaws too much to really time it. I'm going use 4 blocks of puts, buying at certain levels and get out at others. While leaving the last block in case it craters. Even plan on selling OTM puts (weeklys) on big dips. Long GMCR too. Good luck on Wed. And long MNST because the 'bots still need to work and I see them moving in on that one. - PJ
